awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Computational and Experimental Studies on Dynamic Interactions With Soft Soil
awd_abstract_narration:
Locomotion on soft soil is important for many navigation and exploration operations, including explorations for coastal, petroleum, and fresh water resources, extraterrestrial terrain navigation, mapping operations for mine and radiation detection, and search and rescue operations.  In general, motions on soft or loose soil require high energy expenditures compared to motions on packed surfaces. Through support of this award, fundamental research will be pursued to gain further understanding of locomotive interactions with different granular media. This research will draw upon knowledge from various areas, including soil modeling, numerical simulations, vehicle dynamics, and data mining. A salient impact is expected to be the advancement of our understanding of vehicle maneuverability in granular media and related strategies for energy efficiency.  The cross-disciplinary research will provide exceptional learning opportunities for the researchers involved and also usher in new generation of researchers trained in computational modeling and sciences. 

Guided by the team's prior efforts in computational and experimental dynamics, nonlinear phenomena, and fluid-structure interactions, this research effort will be pursued with a focus on understanding granular media interactions associated with wheeled and legged locomotion on soft soils. Original experiments will be conducted by using photo-elastic granules to examine inter-granular force chain development in response to local surface disturbances generated by external loading. These experiments are expected to generate data for simulations of granular interactions based on discrete element models. These simulations will leverage GPU computing. Continuum, geomechanical-hydrodynamic simulations will be used to associate observed force chains with specific soil types. The research effort will help answer basic questions such as the following: i) Can force chains be used to predict slipping in soft-soil interactions? ii) Does an optimum gait speed exist at which soil slipping is minimized? iii) Can spheres, combined with complex friction models, accurately simulate interactions of sand grains and other non-spherically shaped bodies in a statistically averaged sense? and iv) Can one apply statistical distributions such as the Tracy-Widom distribution to interactions with granular media?  The findings are expected to provide a unique means for interrogating granular reactions to locomotive interactions in a way not tractable through experimentation alone. The outcomes are expected to be useful for developing efficient propulsion strategies for robot platforms that span a range of different sizes, weights, speeds, and energy consumption targets.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Soft-soil navigation and exploration are vital for coastline explorations, petroleum and fresh water resources, extraterrestrial explorations, and mine and radiation detection in beach and other similar environments. For carrying out such navigations and explorations, an excellent understanding of the interactions that take place between the vehicle (robot) and the media being traversed is needed.  To this end, computational and experimental studies have been employed to better understand the interactions between a robot appendage (leg or wheel) and dry and wet granular media. The methods and approaches developed in this work are applicable to a diverse range of areas ranging from robot maneuvering studies to manufacturing processes (additive and subtractive manufacturing, powder manufacturing, welding) to modeling of mud slides.  

 

A multi-year effort has been pursued by a group of researchers from the University of Maryland.  This group includes two faculty member, graduate and undergraduate students, and a post-doctoral researcher from Mechanical Engineering and Applied Mathematics and Scientific Computation. Through numerical-experimental studies, the researchers have gained insights into how continuum simulations based on smooth particle hydrodynamics can be used to study interactions with wet granular media.  In addition, discrete element method based studies have been used to elucidate lugged wheel interactions with granular media, formation of force chains in the media, and wheel performance in terms of sinkage, slippage, and traction.  The companion experimental studies have helped visualize how force chains are formed during the interactions of a driven pendulum with a photoelastic granular bed. The findings from the computational studies have been brought is as illustrative examples in a dynamics course. The cross-disciplinary research has provided exceptional learning opportunities for multiple graduate and undergraduate students and a post-doctoral researcher. Different experiments, simulations, and visualizations have been featured in annual exhibits to visitors from government laboratories, academia, and local schools to stimulate interest in engineering and sciences.  In addition, to broaden the dissemination and connect with data sciences, poster exhibits have been prepared and displayed at domestic supercomputing conferences.

 

Two graduate students, one undergraduate student, and a post-doctoral researcher have directly benefited from the research efforts. The undergraduate student has developed an interest in robotics and data sciences following participation in the project.  She is currently pursuing computer engineering. One of the doctoral students plans to pursue a career in academia following her graduation, while the other doctoral student plans to pursue a career in industry with a focus on data sciences. The female post-doctoral researcher has benefited from this work and plans to pursue an academic career in the future. 

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2019
Modified by: Balakumar Balachandran
